text: Now there was a certain man of Ramathaim Zophim, of the hill country of Ephraim, and his name was Elkanah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had two wives. The name of one was Hannah, and the name of the other Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man went up out of his city from year to year to worship and to sacrifice to Yahweh of Armies in Shiloh. The two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, priests to Yahweh, were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the day came that Elkanah sacrificed, he gave portions to Peninnah his wife and to all her sons and her daughters;
speaker: Narrator

text: but he gave a double portion to Hannah, for he loved Hannah, but Yahweh had shut up her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her rival provoked her severely, to irritate her, because Yahweh had shut up her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: So year by year, when she went up to Yahweh’s house, her rival provoked her. Therefore she wept, and didn’t eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah her husband said to her, “Hannah, why do you weep? Why don’t you eat? Why is your heart grieved? Am I not better to you than ten sons?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hannah rose up after they had finished eating and drinking in Shiloh. Now Eli the priest was sitting on his seat by the doorpost of Yahweh’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was in bitterness of soul, and prayed to Yahweh, weeping bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: She vowed a vow, and said, “Yahweh of Armies, if you will indeed look at the affliction of your servant and remember me, and not forget your servant, but will give to your servant a boy, then I will give him to Yahweh all the days of his life, and no razor shall come on his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As she continued praying before Yahweh, Eli saw her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Hannah spoke in her heart. Only her lips moved, but her voice was not heard. Therefore Eli thought she was drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli said to her, “How long will you be drunk? Get rid of your wine!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah answered, “No, my lord, I am a woman of a sorrowful spirit. I have not been drinking wine or strong drink, but I poured out my soul before Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t consider your servant a wicked woman; for I have been speaking out of the abundance of my complaint and my provocation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eli answered, “Go in peace; and may the God of Israel grant your petition that you have asked of him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Let your servant find favor in your sight.” So the woman went her way and ate; and her facial expression wasn’t sad any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rose up in the morning early and worshiped Yahweh, then returned and came to their house to Ramah. Then Elkanah knew Hannah his wife; and Yahweh remembered her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time had come, Hannah conceived, and bore a son; and she named him Samuel, saying, “Because I have asked him of Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man Elkanah, and all his house, went up to offer to Yahweh the yearly sacrifice and his vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hannah didn’t go up, for she said to her husband, “Not until the child is weaned; then I will bring him, that he may appear before Yahweh, and stay there forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elkanah her husband said to her, “Do what seems good to you. Wait until you have weaned him; only may Yahweh establish his word.”
So the woman waited and nursed her son until she weaned him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had weaned him, she took him up with her, with three bulls, and one ephah of meal, and a container of wine, and brought him to Yahweh’s house in Shiloh. The child was young.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed the bull, and brought the child to Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Oh, my lord, as your soul lives, my lord, I am the woman who stood by you here, praying to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: I prayed for this child, and Yahweh has given me my petition which I asked of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I have also given him to Yahweh. As long as he lives he is given to Yahweh.” He worshiped Yahweh there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hannah prayed, and said,
“My heart exults in Yahweh!
    My horn is exalted in Yahweh.
My mouth is enlarged over my enemies,
    because I rejoice in your salvation.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Don’t keep talking so exceedingly proudly.
    Don’t let arrogance come out of your mouth,
    for Yahweh is a God of knowledge.
    By him actions are weighed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The bows of the mighty men are broken.
    Those who stumbled are armed with strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who were full have hired themselves out for bread.
    Those who were hungry are satisfied.
Yes, the barren has borne seven.
    She who has many children languishes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yahweh kills and makes alive.
    He brings down to Sheol and brings up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh makes poor and makes rich.
    He brings low, he also lifts up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He raises up the poor out of the dust.
    He lifts up the needy from the dunghill
    to make them sit with princes
    and inherit the throne of glory.
For the pillars of the earth are Yahweh’s.
    He has set the world on them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Those who strive with Yahweh shall be broken to pieces.
    He will thunder against them in the sky. 
“Yahweh will judge the ends of the earth.
    He will give strength to his king,
    and exalt the horn of his anointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah went to Ramah to his house. The child served Yahweh before Eli the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sons of Eli were wicked men. They didn’t know Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The custom of the priests with the people was that when anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest’s servant came while the meat was boiling, with a fork of three teeth in his hand;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he stabbed it into the pan, or kettle, or cauldron, or pot. The priest took all that the fork brought up for himself. They did this to all the Israelites who came there to Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, before they burned the fat, the priest’s servant came, and said to the man who sacrificed, “Give meat to roast for the priest; for he will not accept boiled meat from you, but raw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If the man said to him, “Let the fat be burned first, and then take as much as your soul desires;” then he would say, “No, but you shall give it to me now; and if not, I will take it by force.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sin of the young men was very great before Yahweh; for the men despised Yahweh’s offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samuel ministered before Yahweh, being a child, clothed with a linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover his mother made him a little robe, and brought it to him from year to year when she came up with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli blessed Elkanah and his wife, and said, “May Yahweh give you offspring from this woman for the petition which was asked of Yahweh.” Then they went to their own home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh visited Hannah, and she conceived and bore three sons and two daughters. The child Samuel grew before Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Eli was very old; and he heard all that his sons did to all Israel, and how that they slept with the women who served at the door of the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Why do you do such things? For I hear of your evil dealings from all these people.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, my sons; for it is not a good report that I hear! You make Yahweh’s people disobey.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one man sins against another, God will judge him; but if a man sins against Yahweh, who will intercede for him?” Notwithstanding, they didn’t listen to the voice of their father, because Yahweh intended to kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The child Samuel grew on, and increased in favor both with Yahweh and also with men.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of God came to Eli and said to him, “Yahweh says, ‘Did I reveal myself to the house of your father when they were in Egypt in bondage to Pharaoh’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t I choose him out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, to wear an ephod before me? Didn’t I give to the house of your father all the offerings of the children of Israel made by fire?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you kick at my sacrifice and at my offering, which I have commanded in my habitation, and honor your sons above me, to make yourselves fat with the best of all the offerings of Israel my people?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore Yahweh, the God of Israel, says, ‘I said indeed that your house and the house of your father should walk before me forever.’ But now Yahweh says, ‘Far be it from me; for those who honor me I will honor, and those who despise me will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the days come that I will cut off your arm and the arm of your father’s house, that there will not be an old man in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will see the affliction of my habitation, in all the wealth which I will give Israel. There shall not be an old man in your house forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of yours whom I don’t cut off from my altar will consume your eyes and grieve your heart. All the increase of your house will die in the flower of their age.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be the sign to you that will come on your two sons, on Hophni and Phinehas: in one day they will both die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will raise up a faithful priest for myself who will do according to that which is in my heart and in my mind. I will build him a sure house. He will walk before my anointed forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will happen that everyone who is left in your house will come and bow down to him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread, and will say, “Please put me into one of the priests’ offices, that I may eat a morsel of bread.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The child Samuel ministered to Yahweh before Eli. Yahweh’s word was rare in those days. There were not many visions, then.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, when Eli was laid down in his place (now his eyes had begun to grow dim, so that he could not see),
speaker: Narrator

text: and God’s lamp hadn’t yet gone out, and Samuel had laid down in Yahweh’s temple where God’s ark was,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh called Samuel. He said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ran to Eli and said, “Here I am; for you called me.”
He said, “I didn’t call. Lie down again.”
He went and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh called yet again, “Samuel!”
Samuel arose and went to Eli and said, “Here I am; for you called me.”
He answered, “I didn’t call, my son. Lie down again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel didn’t yet know Yahweh, neither was Yahweh’s word yet revealed to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh called Samuel again the third time. He arose and went to Eli and said, “Here I am; for you called me.”
Eli perceived that Yahweh had called the child.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Eli said to Samuel, “Go, lie down. It shall be, if he calls you, that you shall say, ‘Speak, Yahweh; for your servant hears.’” So Samuel went and lay down in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh came, and stood, and called as at other times, “Samuel! Samuel!”
Then Samuel said, “Speak; for your servant hears.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Samuel, “Behold, I will do a thing in Israel at which both the ears of everyone who hears it will tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day I will perform against Eli all that I have spoken concerning his house, from the beginning even to the end.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have told him that I will judge his house forever for the iniquity which he knew, because his sons brought a curse on themselves, and he didn’t restrain them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I have sworn to the house of Eli that the iniquity of Eli’s house shall not be removed with sacrifice or offering forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel lay until the morning, and opened the doors of Yahweh’s house. Samuel was afraid to show Eli the vision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Eli called Samuel and said, “Samuel, my son!”
He said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What is the thing that he has spoken to you? Please don’t hide it from me. God do so to you, and more also, if you hide anything from me of all the things that he spoke to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel told him every bit, and hid nothing from him.
He said, “It is Yahweh. Let him do what seems good to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel grew, and Yahweh was with him and let none of his words fall to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel from Dan even to Beersheba knew that Samuel was established to be a prophet of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh appeared again in Shiloh; for Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel in Shiloh by Yahweh’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The word of Samuel came to all Israel.
Now Israel went out against the Philistines to battle, and encamped beside Ebenezer; and the Philistines encamped in Aphek.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines put themselves in array against Israel. When they joined battle, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand men of the army in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people had come into the camp, the elders of Israel said, “Why has Yahweh defeated us today before the Philistines? Let’s get the ark of Yahweh’s covenant out of Shiloh and bring it to us, that it may come among us and save us out of the hand of our enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people sent to Shiloh, and they brought from there the ark of the covenant of Yahweh of Armies, who sits above the cherubim; and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ark of Yahweh’s covenant came into the camp, all Israel shouted with a great shout, so that the earth resounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard the noise of the shout, they said, “What does the noise of this great shout in the camp of the Hebrews mean?” They understood that Yahweh’s ark had come into the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines were afraid, for they said, “God has come into the camp.” They said, “Woe to us! For there has not been such a thing before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe to us! Who shall deliver us out of the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods that struck the Egyptians with all kinds of plagues in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and behave like men, O you Philistines, that you not be servants to the Hebrews, as they have been to you. Strengthen yourselves like men, and fight!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, and each man fled to his tent. There was a very great slaughter; for thirty thousand footmen of Israel fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: God’s ark was taken; and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were slain.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of Benjamin ran out of the army and came to Shiloh the same day, with his clothes torn and with dirt on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came, behold, Eli was sitting on his seat by the road watching, for his heart trembled for God’s ark. When the man came into the city and told about it, all the city cried out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Eli heard the noise of the crying, he said, “What does the noise of this tumult mean?”
The man hurried, and came and told Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Eli was ninety-eight years old. His eyes were set, so that he could not see.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man said to Eli, “I am he who came out of the army, and I fled today out of the army.”
He said, “How did the matter go, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He who brought the news answered, “Israel has fled before the Philistines, and there has been also a great slaughter among the people. Your two sons also, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead, and God’s ark has been captured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he made mention of God’s ark, Eli fell from off his seat backward by the side of the gate; and his neck broke, and he died, for he was an old man and heavy. He had judged Israel forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: His daughter-in-law, Phinehas’ wife, was with child, near to giving birth. When she heard the news that God’s ark was taken and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she bowed herself and gave birth; for her pains came on her.
speaker: Narrator

text: About the time of her death the women who stood by her said to her, “Don’t be afraid, for you have given birth to a son.” But she didn’t answer, neither did she regard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: She named the child Ichabod, saying, “The glory has departed from Israel!” because God’s ark was taken, and because of her father-in-law and her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “The glory has departed from Israel; for God’s ark has been taken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines had taken God’s ark, and they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines took God’s ark, and brought it into the house of Dagon and set it by Dagon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Ashdod arose early on the next day, behold, Dagon had fallen on his face to the ground before Yahweh’s ark. They took Dagon and set him in his place again.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arose early on the following morning, behold, Dagon had fallen on his face to the ground before Yahweh’s ark; and the head of Dagon and both the palms of his hands were cut off on the threshold. Only Dagon’s torso was intact.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore neither the priests of Dagon nor any who come into Dagon’s house step on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Yahweh’s hand was heavy on the people of Ashdod, and he destroyed them and struck them with tumors, even Ashdod and its borders.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Ashdod saw that it was so, they said, “The ark of the God of Israel shall not stay with us, for his hand is severe on us and on Dagon our god.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sent therefore and gathered together all the lords of the Philistines, and said, “What shall we do with the ark of the God of Israel?”
They answered, “Let the ark of the God of Israel be carried over to Gath.” They carried the ark of the God of Israel there.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was so, that after they had carried it there, Yahweh’s hand was against the city with a very great confusion; and he struck the men of the city, both small and great, so that tumors broke out on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they sent God’s ark to Ekron.
As God’s ark came to Ekron, the Ekronites cried out, saying, “They have brought the ark of the God of Israel here to us, to kill us and our people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent therefore and gathered together all the lords of the Philistines, and they said, “Send the ark of the God of Israel away, and let it go again to its own place, that it not kill us and our people.” For there was a deadly panic throughout all the city. The hand of God was very heavy there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men who didn’t die were struck with the tumors; and the cry of the city went up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh’s ark was in the country of the Philistines seven months.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines called for the priests and the diviners, saying, “What shall we do with Yahweh’s ark? Show us how we should send it to its place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “If you send away the ark of the God of Israel, don’t send it empty; but by all means return a trespass offering to him. Then you will be healed, and it will be known to you why his hand is not removed from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they said, “What should the trespass offering be which we shall return to him?”
They said, “Five golden tumors and five golden mice, for the number of the lords of the Philistines; for one plague was on you all, and on your lords.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you shall make images of your tumors and images of your mice that mar the land; and you shall give glory to the God of Israel. Perhaps he will release his hand from you, from your gods, and from your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then do you harden your hearts as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? When he had worked wonderfully among them, didn’t they let the people go, and they departed?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore take and prepare yourselves a new cart and two milk cows on which there has come no yoke; and tie the cows to the cart, and bring their calves home from them;
speaker: Narrator

text: and take Yahweh’s ark and lay it on the cart. Put the jewels of gold, which you return him for a trespass offering, in a box by its side; and send it away, that it may go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, if it goes up by the way of its own border to Beth Shemesh, then he has done us this great evil; but if not, then we shall know that it is not his hand that struck us. It was a chance that happened to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men did so, and took two milk cows and tied them to the cart, and shut up their calves at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put Yahweh’s ark on the cart, and the box with the golden mice and the images of their tumors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cows took the straight way by the way to Beth Shemesh. They went along the highway, lowing as they went, and didn’t turn away to the right hand or to the left; and the lords of the Philistines went after them to the border of Beth Shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Beth Shemesh were reaping their wheat harvest in the valley; and they lifted up their eyes and saw the ark, and rejoiced to see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cart came into the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh, and stood there, where there was a great stone. Then they split the wood of the cart and offered up the cows for a burnt offering to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites took down Yahweh’s ark and the box that was with it, in which the jewels of gold were, and put them on the great stone; and the men of Beth Shemesh offered burnt offerings and sacrificed sacrifices the same day to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the five lords of the Philistines had seen it, they returned to Ekron the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the golden tumors which the Philistines returned for a trespass offering to Yahweh: for Ashdod one, for Gaza one, for Ashkelon one, for Gath one, for Ekron one;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the golden mice, according to the number of all the cities of the Philistines belonging to the five lords, both of fortified cities and of country villages, even to the great stone on which they set down Yahweh’s ark. That stone remains to this day in the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck of the men of Beth Shemesh, because they had looked into Yahweh’s ark, he struck fifty thousand seventy of the men. Then the people mourned, because Yahweh had struck the people with a great slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Beth Shemesh said, “Who is able to stand before Yahweh, this holy God? To whom shall he go up from us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kiriath Jearim, saying, “The Philistines have brought back Yahweh’s ark. Come down and bring it up to yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Kiriath Jearim came and took Yahweh’s ark, and brought it into Abinadab’s house on the hill, and consecrated Eleazar his son to keep Yahweh’s ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the day that the ark stayed in Kiriath Jearim, the time was long—for it was twenty years; and all the house of Israel lamented after Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel spoke to all the house of Israel, saying, “If you are returning to Yahweh with all your heart, then put away the foreign gods and the Ashtaroth from among you, and direct your hearts to Yahweh, and serve him only; and he will deliver you out of the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the children of Israel removed the Baals and the Ashtaroth, and served Yahweh only.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Gather all Israel to Mizpah, and I will pray to Yahweh for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They gathered together to Mizpah, and drew water, and poured it out before Yahweh, and fasted on that day, and said there, “We have sinned against Yahweh.” Samuel judged the children of Israel in Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that the children of Israel were gathered together at Mizpah, the lords of the Philistines went up against Israel. When the children of Israel heard it, they were afraid of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel said to Samuel, “Don’t stop crying to Yahweh our God for us, that he will save us out of the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel took a suckling lamb, and offered it for a whole burnt offering to Yahweh. Samuel cried to Yahweh for Israel, and Yahweh answered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel was offering up the burnt offering, the Philistines came near to battle against Israel; but Yahweh thundered with a great thunder on that day on the Philistines and confused them; and they were struck down before Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel went out of Mizpah and pursued the Philistines, and struck them until they came under Beth Kar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took a stone and set it between Mizpah and Shen, and called its name Ebenezer, saying, “Yahweh helped us until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines were subdued, and they stopped coming within the border of Israel. Yahweh’s hand was against the Philistines all the days of Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cities which the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to Israel, from Ekron even to Gath; and Israel recovered its border out of the hand of the Philistines. There was peace between Israel and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went from year to year in a circuit to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah; and he judged Israel in all those places.
speaker: Narrator

text: His return was to Ramah, for his house was there, and he judged Israel there; and he built an altar to Yahweh there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel was old, he made his sons judges over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the name of his firstborn was Joel, and the name of his second, Abijah. They were judges in Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons didn’t walk in his ways, but turned away after dishonest gain, took bribes, and perverted justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the elders of Israel gathered themselves together and came to Samuel to Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Behold, you are old, and your sons don’t walk in your ways. Now make us a king to judge us like all the nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the thing displeased Samuel when they said, “Give us a king to judge us.”
Samuel prayed to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Samuel, “Listen to the voice of the people in all that they tell you; for they have not rejected you, but they have rejected me as the king over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to all the works which they have done since the day that I brought them up out of Egypt even to this day, in that they have forsaken me and served other gods, so they also do to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, listen to their voice. However, you shall protest solemnly to them, and shall show them the way of the king who will reign over them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told all Yahweh’s words to the people who asked him for a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “This will be the way of the king who shall reign over you: he will take your sons and appoint them as his servants, for his chariots and to be his horsemen; and they will run before his chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will appoint them to him for captains of thousands and captains of fifties; and he will assign some to plow his ground and to reap his harvest; and to make his instruments of war and the instruments of his chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your daughters to be perfumers, to be cooks, and to be bakers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your fields, your vineyards, and your olive groves, even your best, and give them to his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take one tenth of your seed and of your vineyards, and give it to his officers and to his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your male servants, your female servants, your best young men, and your donkeys, and assign them to his own work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take one tenth of your flocks; and you will be his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will cry out in that day because of your king whom you will have chosen for yourselves; and Yahweh will not answer you in that day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people refused to listen to the voice of Samuel; and they said, “No, but we will have a king over us,
speaker: Narrator

text: that we also may be like all the nations; and that our king may judge us, and go out before us, and fight our battles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel heard all the words of the people, and he rehearsed them in the ears of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh said to Samuel, “Listen to their voice, and make them a king.”
Samuel said to the men of Israel, “Everyone go to your own city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a man of Benjamin, whose name was Kish the son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Becorath, the son of Aphiah, the son of a Benjamite, a mighty man of valor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a son whose name was Saul, an impressive young man; and there was not among the children of Israel a more handsome person than he. From his shoulders and upward he was taller than any of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkeys of Kish, Saul’s father, were lost. Kish said to Saul his son, “Now take one of the servants with you, and arise, go look for the donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He passed through the hill country of Ephraim, and passed through the land of Shalishah, but they didn’t find them. Then they passed through the land of Shaalim, and they weren’t there. Then he passed through the land of the Benjamites, but they didn’t find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come to the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant who was with him, “Come! Let’s return, lest my father stop caring about the donkeys and be anxious for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant said to him, “Behold now, there is a man of God in this city, and he is a man who is held in honor. All that he says surely happens. Now let’s go there. Perhaps he can tell us which way to go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to his servant, “But behold, if we go, what should we bring the man? For the bread is spent in our sacks, and there is not a present to bring to the man of God. What do we have?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant answered Saul again and said, “Behold, I have in my hand the fourth part of a shekel of silver. I will give that to the man of God, to tell us our way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (In earlier times in Israel, when a man went to inquire of God, he said, “Come! Let’s go to the seer;” for he who is now called a prophet was before called a seer.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to his servant, “Well said. Come! Let’s go.” So they went to the city where the man of God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they went up the ascent to the city, they found young maidens going out to draw water, and said to them, “Is the seer here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered them and said, “He is. Behold, he is before you. Hurry now, for he has come today into the city; for the people have a sacrifice today in the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as you have come into the city, you will immediately find him before he goes up to the high place to eat; for the people will not eat until he comes, because he blesses the sacrifice. Afterwards those who are invited eat. Now therefore go up; for at this time you will find him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up to the city. As they came within the city, behold, Samuel came out toward them to go up to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Yahweh had revealed to Samuel a day before Saul came, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tomorrow about this time I will send you a man out of the land of Benjamin, and you shall anoint him to be prince over my people Israel. He will save my people out of the hand of the Philistines; for I have looked upon my people, because their cry has come to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel saw Saul, Yahweh said to him, “Behold, the man of whom I spoke to you! He will have authority over my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul approached Samuel in the gateway, and said, “Please tell me where the seer’s house is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel answered Saul and said, “I am the seer. Go up before me to the high place, for you are to eat with me today. In the morning I will let you go and will tell you all that is in your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for your donkeys who were lost three days ago, don’t set your mind on them, for they have been found. For whom does all Israel desire? Is it not you and all your father’s house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul answered, “Am I not a Benjamite, of the smallest of the tribes of Israel? And my family the least of all the families of the tribe of Benjamin? Why then do you speak to me like this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel took Saul and his servant and brought them into the guest room, and made them sit in the best place among those who were invited, who were about thirty persons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the cook, “Bring the portion which I gave you, of which I said to you, ‘Set it aside.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The cook took up the thigh, and that which was on it, and set it before Saul. Samuel said, “Behold, that which has been reserved! Set it before yourself and eat; because it has been kept for you for the appointed time, for I said, ‘I have invited the people.’” So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come down from the high place into the city, he talked with Saul on the housetop.
speaker: Narrator

text: They arose early; and about daybreak, Samuel called to Saul on the housetop, saying, “Get up, that I may send you away.” Saul arose, and they both went outside, he and Samuel, together.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going down at the end of the city, Samuel said to Saul, “Tell the servant to go on ahead of us.” He went ahead, then Samuel said, “But stand still first, that I may cause you to hear God’s message.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took the vial of oil and poured it on his head, then kissed him and said, “Hasn’t Yahweh anointed you to be prince over his inheritance?
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have departed from me today, then you will find two men by Rachel’s tomb, on the border of Benjamin at Zelzah. They will tell you, ‘The donkeys which you went to look for have been found; and behold, your father has stopped caring about the donkeys and is anxious for you, saying, “What shall I do for my son?”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you will go on forward from there, and you will come to the oak of Tabor. Three men will meet you there going up to God to Bethel: one carrying three young goats, and another carrying three loaves of bread, and another carrying a container of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you shall receive from their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After that you will come to the hill of God, where the garrison of the Philistines is; and it will happen, when you have come there to the city, that you will meet a band of prophets coming down from the high place with a lute, a tambourine, a pipe, and a harp before them; and they will be prophesying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh’s Spirit will come mightily on you, then you will prophesy with them and will be turned into another man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let it be, when these signs have come to you, that you do what is appropriate for the occasion; for God is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go down ahead of me to Gilgal; and behold, I will come down to you to offer burnt offerings and to sacrifice sacrifices of peace offerings. Wait seven days, until I come to you and show you what you are to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was so, that when he had turned his back to go from Samuel, God gave him another heart; and all those signs happened that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came there to the hill, behold, a band of prophets met him; and the Spirit of God came mightily on him, and he prophesied among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all who knew him before saw that, behold, he prophesied with the prophets, then the people said to one another, “What is this that has come to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: One from the same place answered, “Who is their father?” Therefore it became a proverb, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished prophesying, he came to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul’s uncle said to him and to his servant, “Where did you go?”
He said, “To seek the donkeys. When we saw that they were not found, we came to Samuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s uncle said, “Please tell me what Samuel said to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his uncle, “He told us plainly that the donkeys were found.” But concerning the matter of the kingdom, of which Samuel spoke, he didn’t tell him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel called the people together to Yahweh to Mizpah;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to the children of Israel, “Yahweh, the God of Israel, says ‘I brought Israel up out of Egypt and I delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians, and out of the hand of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have today rejected your God, who himself saves you out of all your calamities and your distresses; and you have said to him, ‘No! Set a king over us!’ Now therefore present yourselves before Yahweh by your tribes and by your thousands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel brought all the tribes of Israel near, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the tribe of Benjamin near by their families and the family of the Matrites was chosen. Then Saul the son of Kish was chosen; but when they looked for him, he could not be found.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore they asked of Yahweh further, “Is there yet a man to come here?”
Yahweh answered, “Behold, he has hidden himself among the baggage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They ran and got him there. When he stood among the people, he was higher than any of the people from his shoulders and upward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said to all the people, “Do you see him whom Yahweh has chosen, that there is no one like him among all the people?”
All the people shouted and said, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel told the people the regulations of the kingdom, and wrote it in a book and laid it up before Yahweh. Samuel sent all the people away, every man to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul also went to his house in Gibeah; and the army went with him, whose hearts God had touched.
speaker: Narrator

text: But certain worthless fellows said, “How could this man save us?” They despised him, and brought him no tribute. But he held his peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nahash the Ammonite came up and encamped against Jabesh Gilead; and all the men of Jabesh said to Nahash, “Make a covenant with us, and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahash the Ammonite said to them, “On this condition I will make it with you, that all your right eyes be gouged out. I will make this dishonor all Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Jabesh said to him, “Give us seven days, that we may send messengers to all the borders of Israel; and then, if there is no one to save us, we will come out to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the messengers came to Gibeah of Saul, and spoke these words in the ears of the people, then all the people lifted up their voice and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, Saul came following the oxen out of the field; and Saul said, “What ails the people that they weep?” They told him the words of the men of Jabesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: God’s Spirit came mightily on Saul when he heard those words, and his anger burned hot.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took a yoke of oxen and cut them in pieces, then sent them throughout all the borders of Israel by the hand of messengers, saying, “Whoever doesn’t come out after Saul and after Samuel, so shall it be done to his oxen.” The dread of Yahweh fell on the people, and they came out as one man.
speaker: Narrator

text: He counted them in Bezek; and the children of Israel were three hundred thousand, and the men of Judah thirty thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to the messengers who came, “Tell the men of Jabesh Gilead, ‘Tomorrow, by the time the sun is hot, you will be rescued.’” The messengers came and told the men of Jabesh; and they were glad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the men of Jabesh said, “Tomorrow we will come out to you, and you shall do with us all that seems good to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, Saul put the people in three companies; and they came into the middle of the camp in the morning watch, and struck the Ammonites until the heat of the day. Those who remained were scattered, so that no two of them were left together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people said to Samuel, “Who is he who said, ‘Shall Saul reign over us?’ Bring those men, that we may put them to death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “No man shall be put to death today; for today Yahweh has rescued Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to the people, “Come! Let’s go to Gilgal, and renew the kingdom there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people went to Gilgal; and there they made Saul king before Yahweh in Gilgal. There they offered sacrifices of peace offerings before Yahweh; and there Saul and all the men of Israel rejoiced greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to all Israel, “Behold, I have listened to your voice in all that you said to me, and have made a king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, behold, the king walks before you. I am old and gray-headed. Behold, my sons are with you. I have walked before you from my youth to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here I am. Witness against me before Yahweh and before his anointed. Whose ox have I taken? Whose donkey have I taken? Whom have I defrauded? Whom have I oppressed? Of whose hand have I taken a bribe to make me blind my eyes? I will restore it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “You have not defrauded us, nor oppressed us, neither have you taken anything from anyone’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them, “Yahweh is witness against you, and his anointed is witness today, that you have not found anything in my hand.”
They said, “He is witness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the people, “It is Yahweh who appointed Moses and Aaron, and that brought your fathers up out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore stand still, that I may plead with you before Yahweh concerning all the righteous acts of Yahweh, which he did to you and to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Jacob had come into Egypt, and your fathers cried to Yahweh, then Yahweh sent Moses and Aaron, who brought your fathers out of Egypt, and made them to dwell in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they forgot Yahweh their God; and he sold them into the hand of Sisera, captain of the army of Hazor, and into the hand of the Philistines, and into the hand of the king of Moab; and they fought against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried to Yahweh, and said, ‘We have sinned, because we have forsaken Yahweh and have served the Baals and the Ashtaroth; but now deliver us out of the hand of our enemies, and we will serve you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh sent Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel, and delivered you out of the hand of your enemies on every side; and you lived in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you saw that Nahash the king of the children of Ammon came against you, you said to me, ‘No, but a king shall reign over us,’ when Yahweh your God was your king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore see the king whom you have chosen and whom you have asked for. Behold, Yahweh has set a king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will fear Yahweh, and serve him, and listen to his voice, and not rebel against the commandment of Yahweh, then both you and also the king who reigns over you are followers of Yahweh your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will not listen to Yahweh’s voice, but rebel against the commandment of Yahweh, then Yahweh’s hand will be against you, as it was against your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore stand still and see this great thing, which Yahweh will do before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t it wheat harvest today? I will call to Yahweh, that he may send thunder and rain; and you will know and see that your wickedness is great, which you have done in Yahweh’s sight, in asking for a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel called to Yahweh, and Yahweh sent thunder and rain that day. Then all the people greatly feared Yahweh and Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people said to Samuel, “Pray for your servants to Yahweh your God, that we not die; for we have added to all our sins this evil, to ask for a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the people, “Don’t be afraid. You have indeed done all this evil; yet don’t turn away from following Yahweh, but serve Yahweh with all your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t turn away to go after vain things which can’t profit or deliver, for they are vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Yahweh will not forsake his people for his great name’s sake, because it has pleased Yahweh to make you a people for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, as for me, far be it from me that I should sin against Yahweh in ceasing to pray for you; but I will instruct you in the good and the right way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only fear Yahweh, and serve him in truth with all your heart; for consider what great things he has done for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you keep doing evil, you will be consumed, both you and your king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned over Israel forty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul chose for himself three thousand men of Israel, of which two thousand were with Saul in Michmash and in the Mount of Bethel, and one thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin. He sent the rest of the people to their own tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan struck the garrison of the Philistines that was in Geba, and the Philistines heard of it. Saul blew the trumpet throughout all the land, saying, “Let the Hebrews hear!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel heard that Saul had struck the garrison of the Philistines, and also that Israel was considered an abomination to the Philistines. The people were gathered together after Saul to Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled themselves together to fight with Israel: thirty thousand chariots, six thousand horsemen, and people as the sand which is on the seashore in multitude. They came up and encamped in Michmash, eastward of Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel saw that they were in trouble (for the people were distressed), then the people hid themselves in caves, in thickets, in rocks, in tombs, and in pits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now some of the Hebrews had gone over the Jordan to the land of Gad and Gilead; but as for Saul, he was yet in Gilgal, and all the people followed him trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stayed seven days, according to the time set by Samuel; but Samuel didn’t come to Gilgal, and the people were scattering from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Bring the burnt offering to me here, and the peace offerings.” He offered the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: It came to pass that as soon as he had finished offering the burnt offering, behold, Samuel came; and Saul went out to meet him, that he might greet him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said, “What have you done?”
Saul said, “Because I saw that the people were scattered from me, and that you didn’t come within the days appointed, and that the Philistines assembled themselves together at Michmash,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore I said, ‘Now the Philistines will come down on me to Gilgal, and I haven’t entreated the favor of Yahweh.’ I forced myself therefore, and offered the burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “You have done foolishly. You have not kept the commandment of Yahweh your God, which he commanded you; for now Yahweh would have established your kingdom on Israel forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now your kingdom will not continue. Yahweh has sought for himself a man after his own heart, and Yahweh has appointed him to be prince over his people, because you have not kept that which Yahweh commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel arose, and went from Gilgal to Gibeah of Benjamin. Saul counted the people who were present with him, about six hundred men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, and Jonathan his son, and the people who were present with them, stayed in Geba of Benjamin; but the Philistines encamped in Michmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: The raiders came out of the camp of the Philistines in three companies: one company turned to the way that leads to Ophrah, to the land of Shual;
speaker: Narrator

text: another company turned the way to Beth Horon; and another company turned the way of the border that looks down on the valley of Zeboim toward the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was no blacksmith found throughout all the land of Israel, for the Philistines said, “Lest the Hebrews make themselves swords or spears”;
speaker: Narrator

text: but all the Israelites went down to the Philistines, each man to sharpen his own plowshare, mattock, ax, and sickle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The price was one payim each to sharpen mattocks, plowshares, pitchforks, axes, and goads.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it came to pass in the day of battle that neither sword nor spear was found in the hand of any of the people who were with Saul and Jonathan; but Saul and Jonathan his son had them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The garrison of the Philistines went out to the pass of Michmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it happened on a day that Jonathan the son of Saul said to the young man who bore his armor, “Come! Let’s go over to the Philistines’ garrison that is on the other side.” But he didn’t tell his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul stayed in the uttermost part of Gibeah under the pomegranate tree which is in Migron; and the people who were with him were about six hundred men,
speaker: Narrator

text: including Ahijah the son of Ahitub, Ichabod’s brother, the son of Phinehas, the son of Eli the priest of Yahweh in Shiloh, wearing an ephod. The people didn’t know that Jonathan was gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Between the passes, by which Jonathan sought to go over to the Philistines’ garrison, there was a rocky crag on the one side and a rocky crag on the other side; and the name of the one was Bozez, and the name of the other Seneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one crag rose up on the north in front of Michmash, and the other on the south in front of Geba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to the young man who bore his armor, “Come! Let’s go over to the garrison of these uncircumcised. It may be that Yahweh will work for us, for there is no restraint on Yahweh to save by many or by few.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His armor bearer said to him, “Do all that is in your heart. Go, and behold, I am with you according to your heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said, “Behold, we will pass over to the men, and we will reveal ourselves to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they say this to us, ‘Wait until we come to you!’ then we will stand still in our place and will not go up to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they say this, ‘Come up to us!’ then we will go up, for Yahweh has delivered them into our hand. This shall be the sign to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Both of them revealed themselves to the garrison of the Philistines; and the Philistines said, “Behold, the Hebrews are coming out of the holes where they had hidden themselves!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men of the garrison answered Jonathan and his armor bearer, and said, “Come up to us, and we will show you something!”
Jonathan said to his armor bearer, “Come up after me, for Yahweh has delivered them into the hand of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan climbed up on his hands and on his feet, and his armor bearer after him, and they fell before Jonathan; and his armor bearer killed them after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: That first slaughter, which Jonathan and his armor bearer made, was about twenty men, within as it were half a furrow’s length in an acre of land.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a trembling in the camp, in the field, and among all the people; the garrison and the raiders also trembled; and the earth quaked, so there was an exceedingly great trembling.
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchmen of Saul in Gibeah of Benjamin looked; and behold, the multitude melted away and scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to the people who were with him, “Count now, and see who is missing from us.” When they had counted, behold, Jonathan and his armor bearer were not there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Ahijah, “Bring God’s ark here.” For God’s ark was with the children of Israel at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Saul talked to the priest, the tumult that was in the camp of the Philistines went on and increased; and Saul said to the priest, “Withdraw your hand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and all the people who were with him were gathered together, and came to the battle; and behold, they were all striking each other with their swords in very great confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Hebrews who were with the Philistines before and who went up with them into the camp from all around, even they also turned to be with the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise all the men of Israel who had hidden themselves in the hill country of Ephraim, when they heard that the Philistines fled, even they also followed hard after them in the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh saved Israel that day; and the battle passed over by Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel were distressed that day; for Saul had adjured the people, saying, “Cursed is the man who eats any food until it is evening, and I am avenged of my enemies.” So none of the people tasted food.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people came into the forest; and there was honey on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people had come to the forest, behold, honey was dripping, but no one put his hand to his mouth, for the people feared the oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jonathan didn’t hear when his father commanded the people with the oath. Therefore he put out the end of the rod that was in his hand and dipped it in the honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth; and his eyes brightened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the people answered, and said, “Your father directly commanded the people with an oath, saying, ‘Cursed is the man who eats food today.’” So the people were faint.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said, “My father has troubled the land. Please look how my eyes have brightened because I tasted a little of this honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more, if perhaps the people had eaten freely today of the plunder of their enemies which they found? For now there has been no great slaughter among the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They struck the Philistines that day from Michmash to Aijalon. The people were very faint;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the people pounced on the plunder, and took sheep, cattle, and calves, and killed them on the ground; and the people ate them with the blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they told Saul, saying, “Behold, the people are sinning against Yahweh, in that they eat meat with the blood.”
He said, “You have dealt treacherously. Roll a large stone to me today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Disperse yourselves among the people, and tell them, ‘Every man bring me here his ox, and every man his sheep, and kill them here, and eat; and don’t sin against Yahweh in eating meat with the blood.’” All the people brought every man his ox with him that night, and killed them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul built an altar to Yahweh. This was the first altar that he built to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “Let’s go down after the Philistines by night, and take plunder among them until the morning light. Let’s not leave a man of them.”
They said, “Do whatever seems good to you.”
Then the priest said, “Let’s draw near here to God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul asked counsel of God: “Shall I go down after the Philistines? Will you deliver them into the hand of Israel?” But he didn’t answer him that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Draw near here, all you chiefs of the people, and know and see in whom this sin has been today.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as Yahweh lives, who saves Israel, though it is in Jonathan my son, he shall surely die.” But there was not a man among all the people who answered him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said to all Israel, “You be on one side, and I and Jonathan my son will be on the other side.”
The people said to Saul, “Do what seems good to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore Saul said to Yahweh, the God of Israel, “Show the right.”
Jonathan and Saul were chosen, but the people escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “Cast lots between me and Jonathan my son.”
Jonathan was selected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul said to Jonathan, “Tell me what you have done!”
Jonathan told him, and said, “I certainly did taste a little honey with the end of the rod that was in my hand; and behold, I must die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “God do so and more also; for you shall surely die, Jonathan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people said to Saul, “Shall Jonathan die, who has worked this great salvation in Israel? Far from it! As Yahweh lives, there shall not one hair of his head fall to the ground, for he has worked with God today!” So the people rescued Jonathan, so he didn’t die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul went up from following the Philistines; and the Philistines went to their own place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Saul had taken the kingdom over Israel, he fought against all his enemies on every side: against Moab, and against the children of Ammon, and against Edom, and against the kings of Zobah, and against the Philistines. Wherever he turned himself, he defeated them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did valiantly and struck the Amalekites, and delivered Israel out of the hands of those who plundered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sons of Saul were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malchishua; and the names of his two daughters were these: the name of the firstborn Merab, and the name of the younger Michal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Saul’s wife was Ahinoam the daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of the captain of his army was Abner the son of Ner, Saul’s uncle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kish was the father of Saul, and Ner the father of Abner was the son of Abiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was severe war against the Philistines all the days of Saul; and when Saul saw any mighty man or any valiant man, he took him into his service.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “Yahweh sent me to anoint you to be king over his people, over Israel. Now therefore listen to the voice of Yahweh’s words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh of Armies says, ‘I remember what Amalek did to Israel, how he set himself against him on the way when he came up out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now go and strike Amalek, and utterly destroy all that they have, and don’t spare them; but kill both man and woman, infant and nursing baby, ox and sheep, camel and donkey.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul summoned the people, and counted them in Telaim, two hundred thousand footmen and ten thousand men of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul came to the city of Amalek, and set an ambush in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to the Kenites, “Go, depart, go down from among the Amalekites, lest I destroy you with them; for you showed kindness to all the children of Israel when they came up out of Egypt.” So the Kenites departed from among the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul struck the Amalekites, from Havilah as you go to Shur, which is before Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took Agag the king of the Amalekites alive, and utterly destroyed all the people with the edge of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul and the people spared Agag and the best of the sheep, of the cattle, of the fat calves, of the lambs, and all that was good, and were not willing to utterly destroy them; but everything that was vile and refuse, that they destroyed utterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh’s word came to Samuel, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “It grieves me that I have set up Saul to be king, for he has turned back from following me, and has not performed my commandments.” Samuel was angry; and he cried to Yahweh all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel rose early to meet Saul in the morning; and Samuel was told, saying, “Saul came to Carmel, and behold, he set up a monument for himself, turned, passed on, and went down to Gilgal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel came to Saul; and Saul said to him, “You are blessed by Yahweh! I have performed the commandment of Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Then what does this bleating of the sheep in my ears and the lowing of the cattle which I hear mean?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “They have brought them from the Amalekites; for the people spared the best of the sheep and of the cattle, to sacrifice to Yahweh your God. We have utterly destroyed the rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel said to Saul, “Stay, and I will tell you what Yahweh said to me last night.”
He said to him, “Say on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Though you were little in your own sight, weren’t you made the head of the tribes of Israel? Yahweh anointed you king over Israel;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Yahweh sent you on a journey, and said, ‘Go, and utterly destroy the sinners the Amalekites, and fight against them until they are consumed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then didn’t you obey Yahweh’s voice, but took the plunder, and did that which was evil in Yahweh’s sight?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Samuel, “But I have obeyed Yahweh’s voice, and have gone the way which Yahweh sent me, and have brought Agag the king of Amalek, and have utterly destroyed the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people took of the plunder, sheep and cattle, the best of the devoted things, to sacrifice to Yahweh your God in Gilgal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Has Yahweh as great delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying Yahweh’s voice? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to listen than the fat of rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: For rebellion is as the sin of witchcraft, and stubbornness is as idolatry and teraphim. Because you have rejected Yahweh’s word, he has also rejected you from being king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Samuel, “I have sinned; for I have transgressed the commandment of Yahweh and your words, because I feared the people and obeyed their voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, please pardon my sin, and turn again with me, that I may worship Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “I will not return with you; for you have rejected Yahweh’s word, and Yahweh has rejected you from being king over Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel turned around to go away, Saul grabbed the skirt of his robe, and it tore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to him, “Yahweh has torn the kingdom of Israel from you today, and has given it to a neighbor of yours who is better than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also the Strength of Israel will not lie nor repent; for he is not a man, that he should repent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “I have sinned; yet please honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel, and come back with me, that I may worship Yahweh your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel went back with Saul; and Saul worshiped Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel said, “Bring Agag the king of the Amalekites here to me!”
Agag came to him cheerfully. Agag said, “Surely the bitterness of death is past.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “As your sword has made women childless, so your mother will be childless among women!” Then Samuel cut Agag in pieces before Yahweh in Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel went to Ramah; and Saul went up to his house to Gibeah of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel came no more to see Saul until the day of his death, but Samuel mourned for Saul. Yahweh grieved that he had made Saul king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to Samuel, “How long will you mourn for Saul, since I have rejected him from being king over Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and go. I will send you to Jesse the Bethlehemite, for I have provided a king for myself among his sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said, “How can I go? If Saul hears it, he will kill me.”
Yahweh said, “Take a heifer with you, and say, ‘I have come to sacrifice to Yahweh.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Call Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you what you shall do. You shall anoint to me him whom I name to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel did that which Yahweh spoke, and came to Bethlehem. The elders of the city came to meet him trembling, and said, “Do you come peaceably?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Peaceably; I have come to sacrifice to Yahweh. Sanctify yourselves, and come with me to the sacrifice.” He sanctified Jesse and his sons, and called them to the sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come, he looked at Eliab, and said, “Surely Yahweh’s anointed is before him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Yahweh said to Samuel, “Don’t look on his face, or on the height of his stature, because I have rejected him; for I don’t see as man sees. For man looks at the outward appearance, but Yahweh looks at the heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse called Abinadab, and made him pass before Samuel. He said, “Yahweh has not chosen this one, either.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse made Shammah to pass by. He said, “Yahweh has not chosen this one, either.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse made seven of his sons to pass before Samuel. Samuel said to Jesse, “Yahweh has not chosen these.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said to Jesse, “Are all your children here?”
He said, “There remains yet the youngest. Behold, he is keeping the sheep.”
Samuel said to Jesse, “Send and get him, for we will not sit down until he comes here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent, and brought him in. Now he was ruddy, with a handsome face and good appearance. Yahweh said, “Arise! Anoint him, for this is he.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the middle of his brothers. Then Yahweh’s Spirit came mightily on David from that day forward. So Samuel rose up and went to Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Yahweh’s Spirit departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from Yahweh troubled him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s servants said to him, “See now, an evil spirit from God troubles you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let our lord now command your servants who are in front of you to seek out a man who is a skillful player on the harp. Then when the evil spirit from God is on you, he will play with his hand, and you will be well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his servants, “Provide me now a man who can play well, and bring him to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the young men answered and said, “Behold, I have seen a son of Jesse the Bethlehemite who is skillful in playing, a mighty man of valor, a man of war, prudent in speech, and a handsome person; and Yahweh is with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Saul sent messengers to Jesse, and said, “Send me David your son, who is with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a container of wine, and a young goat, and sent them by David his son to Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Saul and stood before him. He loved him greatly; and he became his armor bearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent to Jesse, saying, “Please let David stand before me, for he has found favor in my sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the spirit from God was on Saul, David took the harp and played with his hand; so Saul was refreshed and was well, and the evil spirit departed from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines gathered together their armies to battle; and they were gathered together at Socoh, which belongs to Judah, and encamped between Socoh and Azekah in Ephesdammim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and the men of Israel were gathered together, and encamped in the valley of Elah, and set the battle in array against the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines stood on the mountain on the one side, and Israel stood on the mountain on the other side: and there was a valley between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A champion out of the camp of the Philistines named Goliath of Gath, whose height was six cubits and a span went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a helmet of bronze on his head, and he wore a coat of mail; and the weight of the coat was five thousand shekels of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had bronze shin armor on his legs and a bronze javelin between his shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The staff of his spear was like a weaver’s beam; and his spear’s head weighed six hundred shekels of iron. His shield bearer went before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood and cried to the armies of Israel, and said to them, “Why have you come out to set your battle in array? Am I not a Philistine, and you servants to Saul? Choose a man for yourselves, and let him come down to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he is able to fight with me and kill me, then will we be your servants; but if I prevail against him and kill him, then you will be our servants and serve us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said, “I defy the armies of Israel today! Give me a man, that we may fight together!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul and all Israel heard those words of the Philistine, they were dismayed and greatly afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David was the son of that Ephrathite of Bethlehem Judah, whose name was Jesse; and he had eight sons. The man was an elderly old man in the days of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three oldest sons of Jesse had gone after Saul to the battle; and the names of his three sons who went to the battle were Eliab the firstborn, and next to him Abinadab, and the third Shammah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was the youngest; and the three oldest followed Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David went back and forth from Saul to feed his father’s sheep at Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine came near morning and evening, and presented himself forty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse said to David his son, “Now take for your brothers an ephah of this parched grain and these ten loaves, and carry them quickly to the camp to your brothers;
speaker: Narrator

text: and bring these ten cheeses to the captain of their thousand; and see how your brothers are doing, and bring back news.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul, and they, and all the men of Israel were in the valley of Elah, fighting with the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: David rose up early in the morning and left the sheep with a keeper, and took the provisions and went, as Jesse had commanded him. He came to the place of the wagons as the army which was going out to the fight shouted for the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel and the Philistines put the battle in array, army against army.
speaker: Narrator

text: David left his baggage in the hand of the keeper of the baggage and ran to the army, and came and greeted his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he talked with them, behold, the champion, the Philistine of Gath, Goliath by name, came up out of the ranks of the Philistines, and said the same words; and David heard them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Israel, when they saw the man, fled from him and were terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel said, “Have you seen this man who has come up? He has surely come up to defy Israel. The king will give great riches to the man who kills him, and will give him his daughter, and will make his father’s house tax-free in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David spoke to the men who stood by him, saying, “What shall be done to the man who kills this Philistine and takes away the reproach from Israel? For who is this uncircumcised Philistine, that he should defy the armies of the living God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people answered him in this way, saying, “So shall it be done to the man who kills him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab his oldest brother heard when he spoke to the men; and Eliab’s anger burned against David, and he said, “Why have you come down? With whom have you left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know your pride and the evil of your heart; for you have come down that you might see the battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “What have I now done? Is there not a cause?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He turned away from him toward another, and spoke like that again; and the people answered him again the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the words were heard which David spoke, they rehearsed them before Saul; and he sent for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Let no man’s heart fail because of him. Your servant will go and fight with this Philistine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to David, “You are not able to go against this Philistine to fight with him; for you are but a youth, and he a man of war from his youth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Your servant was keeping his father’s sheep; and when a lion or a bear came and took a lamb out of the flock,
speaker: Narrator

text: I went out after him, struck him, and rescued it out of his mouth. When he arose against me, I caught him by his beard, struck him, and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant struck both the lion and the bear. This uncircumcised Philistine shall be as one of them, since he has defied the armies of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said, “Yahweh, who delivered me out of the paw of the lion and out of the paw of the bear, will deliver me out of the hand of this Philistine.”
Saul said to David, “Go! Yahweh will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul dressed David with his clothing. He put a helmet of bronze on his head, and he clad him with a coat of mail.
speaker: Narrator

text: David strapped his sword on his clothing and he tried to move, for he had not tested it. David said to Saul, “I can’t go with these, for I have not tested them.” Then David took them off.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his staff in his hand, and chose for himself five smooth stones out of the brook, and put them in the pouch of his shepherd’s bag which he had. His sling was in his hand; and he came near to the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine walked and came near to David; and the man who bore the shield went before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistine looked around and saw David, he disdained him; for he was but a youth, and ruddy, and had a good looking face.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said to David, “Am I a dog, that you come to me with sticks?” The Philistine cursed David by his gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said to David, “Come to me, and I will give your flesh to the birds of the sky and to the animals of the field.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to the Philistine, “You come to me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin; but I come to you in the name of Yahweh of Armies, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today, Yahweh will deliver you into my hand. I will strike you and take your head from off you. I will give the dead bodies of the army of the Philistines today to the birds of the sky and to the wild animals of the earth, that all the earth may know that there is a God in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and that all this assembly may know that Yahweh doesn’t save with sword and spear; for the battle is Yahweh’s, and he will give you into our hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistine arose, and walked and came near to meet David, David hurried and ran toward the army to meet the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: David put his hand in his bag, took a stone and slung it, and struck the Philistine in his forehead. The stone sank into his forehead, and he fell on his face to the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with a stone, and struck the Philistine and killed him; but there was no sword in David’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David ran, stood over the Philistine, took his sword, drew it out of its sheath, killed him, and cut off his head with it.
When the Philistines saw that their champion was dead, they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel and of Judah arose and shouted, and pursued the Philistines as far as Gai and to the gates of Ekron. The wounded of the Philistines fell down by the way to Shaaraim, even to Gath and to Ekron.
speaker: Narrator
